newsitem.title: USA: U.S. states threaten to pull out of tobacco talks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. states threaten to pull out of tobacco talks.

text.p: U.S. states threatened on Tuesday to withdraw from talks with cigarette companies on a landmark legal settlement unless their demands for greater regulation of tobacco were met.
"If we don't get what we want, we're going home," Mississippi Attorney General Mike Moore, the lead negotiator for the states, told reporters.

Moore said the attorneys general, representing 37 states that have launched lawsuits against the cigarette companies, would continue to negotiate with the companies Tuesday afternoon. But he added, "The deadline is pretty near."
The most contentious issue was Food and Drug Administration regulation of cigarettes.

"We are not going to give in on that no matter what they (the companies) say or do," Moore said. The states are demanding the FDA get full authority to regulate nicotine as a drug. Cigarette companies are resisting this, saying that it could lead to the government eventually banning cigarettes.

Moore also said the states want the tobacco industry to be punished for past conduct and be held liable for future conduct. He gave no further details, but the negotiators had been considering a proposal to cap the legal liability of the cigarette companies in some way.
